info.game_comments:
(Sofia: "Jeopardy! Clue Crew location"--11 letters.)
(Cheryl: New York City!)
(Sofia: You got it!  Done!)

(1, 1).clue: Among the portraits of these rulers in their palace, the plotter Marin Falier is covered by a curtain

(2, 1).clue: 2 brothers, also psychiatrists, discuss fine wine & opera; hilarity ensues

(3, 1).clue: It's the long bone extending from the pelvis down the leg

(4, 1).clue: Wherever she was, Mrs. Calabash knew he was the  schnozzola

(6, 1).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from Central Park.)  My little pal is waiting to hear the ending of this Hans Christian Andersen story about one of his feathered friends

(1, 2).clue: Corte Seconde del Milion is the former home of this explorer known for his "Million Lies"

(2, 2).clue: 4 friends do "nothing" for a half an hour, get paid 6 figures per episode for their trouble

(3, 2).clue: The arms or forelimbs of seals or whales are known as these

(4, 2).clue: Seen here he won the Best Actor Oscar for 1940s "The Philadelphia Story"

(6, 2).clue: If you can "spare" the time, try this, the USA's biggest participatory sport

(1, 3).clue: During this natural event, acqua alta, Venetians go around with their feet wrapped in garbage bags

(2, 3).clue: Dad has 2 hairs on his head, mom's hair is measured in vertical feet, son's hair is represented by 9 points

(3, 3).clue: This small triangular bone in the leg protects a hinged joint

(4, 3).clue: In 1976 he said, "I have looked on a lot of women with lust. I've committed adultery in my heart many times"

(6, 3).clue: Adjective used in the title of the 1973 No. 2 hit heard here

(1, 4).clue: 2-word name for the main street of Venice seen here

(2, 4).clue: Title man leaves gas attendant job in small town; his new boss is Vince Carter (the sergeant, not the hoopster)

(3, 4).clue: (Here's Sarah from our Clue Crew) The exercise I'm performing is the dumbbell curl.  It should help pack some meat on this 2-headed muscle

(4, 4).clue: He's the only man who's been the head coach of both the Dallas Cowboys & the Miami Dolphins

(1, 5).clue: Located on a sandbar, this Venetian beach is one of Europe's most famous

(2, 5).clue: Man buys a New England inn, has 3 next door neighbors but only one ever speaks

(3, 5).clue: A mammal offspring shares its name with this fleshy leg part

(4, 5).clue: This baseball player hit a literary home run with his memoir "Ball Four"

(6, 5).clue: A young or teensy-weensy fish, such as a young salmon or trout

(1, 1).clue: Ogadai had some big stirrups to fill when he succeeded this man as supreme Mongol

(2, 1).clue: It often means "of foreign origin", but put it in front of "dancer" & you've got yourself a stripper

(3, 1).clue: In hair accessories, then sunglasses: Sam Foster &...

(4, 1).clue: Technically, a drama only has one of these; another character may be the antagonist or deuteragonist

(5, 1).clue: Along with lemons, which contain more vitamin C, this citrus fruit was used to prevent scurvy

(6, 1).clue: If an appliance runs at 10 amperes on 115 volts multiply 10 x 115 to get 1,150 of these

(1, 2).clue: (Cheryl at the Waldorf-Astoria) This rocking chair was the very one owned by this American President

(2, 2).clue: In 2001 the Australian state of Victoria banned all Good Friday showings of this '70s film--whatever "possessed" them?

(4, 2).clue: "Cohort" is properly used in the singular to mean a group; it was originally a unit in this army

(5, 2).clue: This state was the first to begin raisin' raisins, in the 19th century

(6, 2).clue: To get the number of these, multiply the number of kilometers by 100,000

(1, 3).clue: Born in 1725, he created scandals in his home of Italy & in France, made love to a lot of women, & died in 1798

(2, 3).clue: A synonym for expatriates, or the title of a James Joyce play about amorous entanglements

(3, 3).clue: In menswear: The Hart brothers, Joseph Schaffner &...

(4, 3).clue: This adjective from the Latin for "native" emphasizes that something is native to an area rather than from outside

(5, 3).clue: Early New England colonists sang about eating this gourd morning & noon, & not just in October

(6, 3).clue: To calculate a pitcher's ERA, divide earned runs by innings pitched & multiply by this

(1, 4).clue: This 3-time Democratic Presidential candidate was called "The Boy Orator of the Platte"

(2, 4).clue: The great silent film "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari" seen here is a prime example of this style of cinema

(4, 4).clue: Musicans cringe when this word meaning "a slow increase in loudness" is used to mean "a climax"

(5, 4).clue: In Matthew 21 Jesus cursed one of these trees for not being fruitful enough

(6, 4).clue: When cooking, to get the number of these in a given number of cups, multiply by 16

(1, 5).clue: England's King Charles II was given this jovial sobriquet, maybe because he had at least 13 mistresses

(2, 5).clue: (Hi, I'm Dana Delany.)  I played the dominatrix boss of an S&M fantasy resort in this 1994 film that co-starred Rosie O'Donnell

(4, 5).clue: This word meaning "reciprocal" may also mean "shared", as when it precedes "friend" in a Dickens title

(5, 5).clue: "Ah, why should life all labor be?" asks Tennyson's "eaters" of this fruit

(6, 5).clue: Have plenty of zeroes on hand when using Einstein's equation of energy with mass multiplied by this, squared

(0, 0).clue: This North American bird is known scientifically as Mimus polyglottos
